Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column5: Homework is something most students dread and claim to be a waste of time and hence, this brought about many contrasting views towards homework being a waste of time. while some people think that homework is a waste of time, I think that home work is actually useful for students. Therefore, I disagree that homework is a waste of time. Firstly, homework acts as a mini test or a revision of a topic you did. So although you might think that you learnt everything you need to learn in school, homework actually tests your application skills. In other words, homework test how you can use what you have learnt to answer questions. Therefore, homeworks can act as a mini test not only to test your knowledge of the topic, but also to test how you answer the topic. Secondly, especially for subjects like mathematics, homework can also act as a practice. Mathematics is a subject that many require practice as the more you practice, the more you get to familiarise the question types that might be tested for an exam. In addition, you do not have to mark your work yourself and if you are unsure of a question or got something wrong, the teacher would be able to go through the homework with the whole class. Thus, I think that homework can act as a practice for students. Lastly, I think that homework works as good revision notes to refer to for example, with the past worksheets or homework you did, you can take note of the questions you got incorrect and memorise the corrections or how to avoid that mistake. Therefore, worksheets can work as a helpful last-minute revision tool. In a nutshell, homework is a very useful learning tool that can play a part in how well you do in an exam. Although only doing homework is not enough to secure your results, I hope that people would start taking homework more seriously as it could play a huge role in you doing well for your examinations.

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column5: Homework is something most students dread and claim to be a waste of time and hence, this brought about many contrasting views towards homework being a waste of time. while some people think that homework is a waste of time, I think that home work is actually useful for students. Therefore, I disagree that homework is a waste of time. Firstly, homework acts as a mini test or a revision of a topic you did. So although you might think that you learnt everything you need to learn in school, homework actually tests your application skills. In other words, homework test how you can use what you have learnt to answer questions. Therefore, homeworks can act as a mini test not only to test your knowledge of the topic, but also to test how you answer the topic. Secondly, especially for subjects like mathematics, homework can also act as a practice. Mathematics is a subject that many require practice as the more you practice, the more you get to familiarise the question types that might be tested for an exam. In addition, you do not have to mark your work yourself and if you are unsure of a question or got something wrong, the teacher would be able to go through the homework with the whole class. Thus, I think that homework can act as a practice for students. Lastly, I think that homework works as good revision notes to refer to for example, with the past worksheets or homework you did, you can take note of the questions you got incorrect and memorise the corrections or how to avoid that mistake. Therefore, worksheets can work as a helpful last-minute revision tool. In a nutshell, homework is a very useful learning tool that can play a part in how well you do in an exam. Although only doing homework is not enough to secure your results, I hope that people would start taking homework more seriously as it could play a huge role in you doing well for your examinations.

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column5: Homework is something most students dread and claim to be a waste of time and hence, this brought about many contrasting views towards homework being a waste of time. while some people think that homework is a waste of time, I think that home work is actually useful for students. Therefore, I disagree that homework is a waste of time. Firstly, homework acts as a mini test or a revision of a topic you did. So although you might think that you learnt everything you need to learn in school, homework actually tests your application skills. In other words, homework test how you can use what you have learnt to answer questions. Therefore, homeworks can act as a mini test not only to test your knowledge of the topic, but also to test how you answer the topic. Secondly, especially for subjects like mathematics, homework can also act as a practice. Mathematics is a subject that many require practice as the more you practice, the more you get to familiarise the question types that might be tested for an exam. In addition, you do not have to mark your work yourself and if you are unsure of a question or got something wrong, the teacher would be able to go through the homework with the whole class. Thus, I think that homework can act as a practice for students. Lastly, I think that homework works as good revision notes to refer to for example, with the past worksheets or homework you did, you can take note of the questions you got incorrect and memorise the corrections or how to avoid that mistake. Therefore, worksheets can work as a helpful last-minute revision tool. In a nutshell, homework is a very useful learning tool that can play a part in how well you do in an exam. Although only doing homework is not enough to secure your results, I hope that people would start taking homework more seriously as it could play a huge role in you doing well for your examinations.

column7:
Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column5:
One day, Jake and his dad were driving to the store. It was a normal afternoon, and the road was not too busy. Jake was looking out the window when, suddenly, a loud crash shook the car.
A red truck had run a stop sign and hit their car from the side. Jake felt a strong jolt, and his seatbelt held him back. His dad quickly turned the wheel to stop the car from going off the road. The car came to a stop, and Jake's heart was beating fast.
His dad asked, “Are you okay?” Jake nodded, but he was scared. People from other cars ran over to help. The driver of the red truck got out and said, “I'm so sorry! I didn't see the sign.”
Soon, a police officer and an ambulance arrived. The paramedics checked Jake and his dad, but they were not hurt. The officer talked to the truck driver and wrote things down.
Jake's dad called a tow truck. “Cars can be fixed,” he said. “What matters is that we're safe.”
Jake looked at the dented car and took a deep breath. It had been a scary day, but he was glad they were okay.

column5:
One day, Jake and his dad were driving to the store. It was a normal afternoon, and the road was not too busy. Jake was looking out the window when, suddenly, a loud crash shook the car.
A red truck had run a stop sign and hit their car from the side. Jake felt a strong jolt, and his seatbelt held him back. His dad quickly turned the wheel to stop the car from going off the road. The car came to a stop, and Jake's heart was beating fast.
His dad asked, “Are you okay?” Jake nodded, but he was scared. People from other cars ran over to help. The driver of the red truck got out and said, “I'm so sorry! I didn't see the sign.”
Soon, a police officer and an ambulance arrived. The paramedics checked Jake and his dad, but they were not hurt. The officer talked to the truck driver and wrote things down.
Jake's dad called a tow truck. “Cars can be fixed,” he said. “What matters is that we're safe.”
Jake looked at the dented car and took a deep breath. It had been a scary day, but he was glad they were okay.

column5:
I used to think that hard work was not necessary and that I could always take shortcuts to achieve my goals. However, one incident changed my mindset forever, teaching me a valuable lesson about perseverance and responsibility.

It all started when my teacher announced that there would be a class mathematics competition. The winner would receive a trophy and a gift voucher. I was thrilled because I had always wanted to be recognised for my achievements. However, instead of practising diligently, I assumed that my natural ability would be enough to win. I only skimmed through a few questions the night before and went to bed early, confident that I would do well.

The next day, I walked into the classroom feeling excited. The competition began, and I was given a set of challenging math problems. As I stared at the questions, my confidence quickly faded. My mind went blank. I realised that I had no idea how to solve most of them. My hands grew clammy, and my heart pounded. I glanced around and saw my classmates deep in thought, solving the problems with ease. At that moment, regret filled me. If only I had prepared properly!

When the results were announced, I did not even make it to the top five. My face burned with embarrassment as my teacher handed the trophy to my best friend, Jason. He had worked tirelessly every day, revising and practising different types of questions. I felt a pang of guilt, knowing that I had taken the competition too lightly.

After school, I congratulated Jason and admitted that I had not put in enough effort. He smiled and said, “Hard work always pays off. You can do better next time if you really try.” His words stuck with me. That day, I made a promise to myself—to never take shortcuts again and to always put in my best effort.

Since then, I have learned the importance of perseverance and responsibility. Success does not come easily; it requires dedication and effort. That competition was a turning point in my life, and I will never forget the lesson it taught me.

column5:
I used to think that hard work was not necessary and that I could always take shortcuts to achieve my goals. However, one incident changed my mindset forever, teaching me a valuable lesson about perseverance and responsibility.

It all started when my teacher announced that there would be a class mathematics competition. The winner would receive a trophy and a gift voucher. I was thrilled because I had always wanted to be recognised for my achievements. However, instead of practising diligently, I assumed that my natural ability would be enough to win. I only skimmed through a few questions the night before and went to bed early, confident that I would do well.

The next day, I walked into the classroom feeling excited. The competition began, and I was given a set of challenging math problems. As I stared at the questions, my confidence quickly faded. My mind went blank. I realised that I had no idea how to solve most of them. My hands grew clammy, and my heart pounded. I glanced around and saw my classmates deep in thought, solving the problems with ease. At that moment, regret filled me. If only I had prepared properly!

When the results were announced, I did not even make it to the top five. My face burned with embarrassment as my teacher handed the trophy to my best friend, Jason. He had worked tirelessly every day, revising and practising different types of questions. I felt a pang of guilt, knowing that I had taken the competition too lightly.

After school, I congratulated Jason and admitted that I had not put in enough effort. He smiled and said, “Hard work always pays off. You can do better next time if you really try.” His words stuck with me. That day, I made a promise to myself—to never take shortcuts again and to always put in my best effort.

Since then, I have learned the importance of perseverance and responsibility. Success does not come easily; it requires dedication and effort. That competition was a turning point in my life, and I will never forget the lesson it taught me.

column5:
Guilt weighed heavily on me as I replayed the argument in my mind. It had all started with a simple misunderstanding, but it had caused a rift between me and my best friend.

Jake and I had been inseparable since childhood. We did everything together, from playing video games and riding our bicycles around the neighbourhood to staying up late talking about life. He was the one person I could always count on, and I never thought anything could come between us. But one day, something happened that made me question our friendship.

I was walking past the school canteen when I heard laughter coming from a group of students. As I got closer, I recognised Jake’s voice among them. My heart sank when I heard my name being mentioned, followed by more laughter. My stomach twisted. Was he making fun of me? Was he telling jokes at my expense? A surge of anger and betrayal coursed through me.

Without waiting to hear more, I turned on my heel and walked away, my mind spinning. I felt humiliated and hurt. How could he, my best friend, talk about me behind my back? That evening, I could not shake the bitterness that filled me. The next day, I confronted him, my emotions bubbling over like a volcano about to erupt.

“How could you do that to me?” I snapped, my hands clenched into fists.

Jake looked confused. “What are you talking about?”

“Don’t play dumb! I heard you laughing about me with your new friends,” I accused, my voice rising.

His expression changed from confusion to hurt. “I wasn’t making fun of you,” he said, his tone defensive.

But I wasn’t in the mood to listen. Without giving him a chance to explain, I stormed off. Over the next few days, I ignored him completely. I avoided him in class, refused to respond to his texts, and even turned away when he tried to talk to me. I convinced myself that I was right to be angry.

It wasn’t until a few days later that I spoke to another friend about what had happened. He looked surprised and told me that I had completely misunderstood the situation. “Jake wasn’t making fun of you,” he said. “He was actually sharing a funny memory about the time you two got lost during last year’s school camp. Everyone was laughing because it was such a ridiculous story, not because they were mocking you.”

A cold wave of realisation washed over me. I had let my anger cloud my judgment. Instead of talking to Jake and finding out the truth, I had assumed the worst and shut him out. I had hurt someone who had always stood by me.

That evening, I mustered the courage to call him. As the phone rang, my heart pounded. What if he was still upset? What if I had ruined our friendship beyond repair?

When Jake picked up, I took a deep breath. “Jake, I’m so sorry,” I said, my voice trembling. “I should’ve trusted you instead of assuming the worst. I realise now that I jumped to conclusions without even giving you a chance to explain.”

There was a pause, and then he let out a small chuckle. “I was wondering when you’d come to your senses,” he said. “I was pretty hurt, you know. But I forgive you. Next time, talk to me first before deciding I’m the bad guy.”

Relief flooded me. I had been lucky—Jake was a true friend, and he was willing to put this behind us. That day, I learned a valuable lesson about trust and communication. Never assume the worst without hearing the full story. Misunderstandings can break even the strongest friendships if we let emotions take control. From that moment on, I promised myself that I would always seek the truth before jumping to conclusions.

That evening, I mustered the courage to call him. As the phone rang, my heart pounded. What if he was still upset? What if I had ruined our friendship beyond repair?

When Jake picked up, I took a deep breath. “Jake, I’m so sorry,” I said, my voice trembling. “I should’ve trusted you instead of assuming the worst. I realise now that I jumped to conclusions without even giving you a chance to explain.”

There was a pause, and then he let out a small chuckle. “I was wondering when you’d come to your senses,” he said. “I was pretty hurt, you know. But I forgive you. Next time, talk to me first before deciding I’m the bad guy.”

Relief flooded me. I had been lucky—Jake was a true friend, and he was willing to put this behind us. That day, I learned a valuable lesson about trust and communication. Never assume the worst without hearing the full story. Misunderstandings can break even the strongest friendships if we let emotions take control. From that moment on, I promised myself that I would always seek the truth before jumping to conclusions.

column5:
Guilt weighed heavily on me as I replayed the argument in my mind. It had all started with a simple misunderstanding, but it had caused a rift between me and my best friend.

Jake and I had been inseparable since childhood. We did everything together, from playing video games and riding our bicycles around the neighbourhood to staying up late talking about life. He was the one person I could always count on, and I never thought anything could come between us. But one day, something happened that made me question our friendship.

I was walking past the school canteen when I heard laughter coming from a group of students. As I got closer, I recognised Jake’s voice among them. My heart sank when I heard my name being mentioned, followed by more laughter. My stomach twisted. Was he making fun of me? Was he telling jokes at my expense? A surge of anger and betrayal coursed through me.

Without waiting to hear more, I turned on my heel and walked away, my mind spinning. I felt humiliated and hurt. How could he, my best friend, talk about me behind my back? That evening, I could not shake the bitterness that filled me. The next day, I confronted him, my emotions bubbling over like a volcano about to erupt.

“How could you do that to me?” I snapped, my hands clenched into fists.

Jake looked confused. “What are you talking about?”

“Don’t play dumb! I heard you laughing about me with your new friends,” I accused, my voice rising.

His expression changed from confusion to hurt. “I wasn’t making fun of you,” he said, his tone defensive.

But I wasn’t in the mood to listen. Without giving him a chance to explain, I stormed off. Over the next few days, I ignored him completely. I avoided him in class, refused to respond to his texts, and even turned away when he tried to talk to me. I convinced myself that I was right to be angry.

It wasn’t until a few days later that I spoke to another friend about what had happened. He looked surprised and told me that I had completely misunderstood the situation. “Jake wasn’t making fun of you,” he said. “He was actually sharing a funny memory about the time you two got lost during last year’s school camp. Everyone was laughing because it was such a ridiculous story, not because they were mocking you.”

A cold wave of realisation washed over me. I had let my anger cloud my judgment. Instead of talking to Jake and finding out the truth, I had assumed the worst and shut him out. I had hurt someone who had always stood by me.

That evening, I mustered the courage to call him. As the phone rang, my heart pounded. What if he was still upset? What if I had ruined our friendship beyond repair?

When Jake picked up, I took a deep breath. “Jake, I’m so sorry,” I said, my voice trembling. “I should’ve trusted you instead of assuming the worst. I realise now that I jumped to conclusions without even giving you a chance to explain.”

There was a pause, and then he let out a small chuckle. “I was wondering when you’d come to your senses,” he said. “I was pretty hurt, you know. But I forgive you. Next time, talk to me first before deciding I’m the bad guy.”

Relief flooded me. I had been lucky—Jake was a true friend, and he was willing to put this behind us. That day, I learned a valuable lesson about trust and communication. Never assume the worst without hearing the full story. Misunderstandings can break even the strongest friendships if we let emotions take control. From that moment on, I promised myself that I would always seek the truth before jumping to conclusions.

column5:
Guilt weighed heavily on me as I replayed the argument in my mind. It had all started with a simple misunderstanding, but it had caused a rift between me and my best friend.

Jake and I had been inseparable since childhood. We did everything together, from playing video games and riding our bicycles around the neighbourhood to staying up late talking about life. He was the one person I could always count on, and I never thought anything could come between us. But one day, something happened that made me question our friendship.

I was walking past the school canteen when I heard laughter coming from a group of students. As I got closer, I recognised Jake’s voice among them. My heart sank when I heard my name being mentioned, followed by more laughter. My stomach twisted. Was he making fun of me? Was he telling jokes at my expense? A surge of anger and betrayal coursed through me.

Without waiting to hear more, I turned on my heel and walked away, my mind spinning. I felt humiliated and hurt. How could he, my best friend, talk about me behind my back? That evening, I could not shake the bitterness that filled me. The next day, I confronted him, my emotions bubbling over like a volcano about to erupt.

“How could you do that to me?” I snapped, my hands clenched into fists.

Jake looked confused. “What are you talking about?”

“Don’t play dumb! I heard you laughing about me with your new friends,” I accused, my voice rising.

His expression changed from confusion to hurt. “I wasn’t making fun of you,” he said, his tone defensive.

But I wasn’t in the mood to listen. Without giving him a chance to explain, I stormed off. Over the next few days, I ignored him completely. I avoided him in class, refused to respond to his texts, and even turned away when he tried to talk to me. I convinced myself that I was right to be angry.

It wasn’t until a few days later that I spoke to another friend about what had happened. He looked surprised and told me that I had completely misunderstood the situation. “Jake wasn’t making fun of you,” he said. “He was actually sharing a funny memory about the time you two got lost during last year’s school camp. Everyone was laughing because it was such a ridiculous story, not because they were mocking you.”

A cold wave of realisation washed over me. I had let my anger cloud my judgment. Instead of talking to Jake and finding out the truth, I had assumed the worst and shut him out. I had hurt someone who had always stood by me.

That evening, I mustered the courage to call him. As the phone rang, my heart pounded. What if he was still upset? What if I had ruined our friendship beyond repair?

When Jake picked up, I took a deep breath. “Jake, I’m so sorry,” I said, my voice trembling. “I should’ve trusted you instead of assuming the worst. I realise now that I jumped to conclusions without even giving you a chance to explain.”

There was a pause, and then he let out a small chuckle. “I was wondering when you’d come to your senses,” he said. “I was pretty hurt, you know. But I forgive you. Next time, talk to me first before deciding I’m the bad guy.”

Relief flooded me. I had been lucky—Jake was a true friend, and he was willing to put this behind us. That day, I learned a valuable lesson about trust and communication. Never assume the worst without hearing the full story. Misunderstandings can break even the strongest friendships if we let emotions take control. From that moment on, I promised myself that I would always seek the truth before jumping to conclusions.
column7:
Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column4: Write a composition of at least 150 words on what you can do to make a difference.
column5:
It was a sunny Sunday morning , the sun shone brillantly in the clear blue sky . Sarah jumped out of bed and got ready to go out. She ran down the stairs and quikly devoured her breakfast ." Mom , let's go ! " Sarah exclaimed . Sarah's Mother had promised Sarah that they would get to adopt a dog today . Sarah had saved up money from the previous yer and will be using it to adopt a dog . 
 Once they reached the adopting centre , Sarah and her mother were greeted with barks . Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . 
 Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.

column4: Write a composition of at least 150 words on what you can do to make a difference.
column5:
It was a sunny Sunday morning , the sun shone brillantly in the clear blue sky . Sarah jumped out of bed and got ready to go out. She ran down the stairs and quikly devoured her breakfast ." Mom , let's go ! " Sarah exclaimed . Sarah's Mother had promised Sarah that they would get to adopt a dog today . Sarah had saved up money from the previous yer and will be using it to adopt a dog . 
 Once they reached the adopting centre , Sarah and her mother were greeted with barks . Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . 
 Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.
column7:
Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column4: Write a composition of at least 150 words on what you can do to make a difference.
column5:
It was a sunny Sunday morning , the sun shone brillantly in the clear blue sky . Sarah jumped out of bed and got ready to go out. She ran down the stairs and quikly devoured her breakfast ." Mom , let's go ! " Sarah exclaimed . Sarah's Mother had promised Sarah that they would get to adopt a dog today . Sarah had saved up money from the previous yer and will be using it to adopt a dog . 
 Once they reached the adopting centre , Sarah and her mother were greeted with barks . Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . 
 Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.
column7:
Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column5:
It was a sunny Sunday morning , the sun shone brillantly in the clear blue sky . Sarah jumped out of bed and got ready to go out. She ran down the stairs and quikly devoured her breakfast ." Mom , let's go ! " Sarah exclaimed . Sarah's Mother had promised Sarah that they would get to adopt a dog today . Sarah had saved up money from the previous yer and will be using it to adopt a dog . 
 Once they reached the adopting centre , Sarah and her mother were greeted with barks . Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . 
 Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.
column6: Provide subtle hints or clues without giving direct answers, allowing students to arrive at the correct answer on their own.
column7:
Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

After reading and viewing your classmates’ responses, write a new paragraph of about 50 words in response to this prompt:

Wildlife parks do more good than harm. 
 
How far do you agree with this statement?

column5: \nIn our rapidly developing society, a child's future is often regarded as the top priority of parents. Many parents hope their children have bright and sustainable futures, and this is often only possible when students ace their examinations. As Singapore is a meritocratic society, only the top percentile can attain the best standard of education. As such, parents often push their children to strive for better grades. However, this pursuit would lead to a highly competitive learning environment where, on one hand, students would find themselves in such an overwhelming learning environment, leading to students having excessive stress and mental strain. Likewise, parents may disapprove of such an overly competitive learning environment, fearing that it might promote an unhealthy perception of education. Meanwhile, governments view competition in schools as a way to find and nurture national talent. Similarly, tuition companies may support a competitive education system, as it motivates worrisome parents to seek extra academic support, ultimately boosting their business. While it is clear that unhealthy competition can be harmful to students, a well-managed and positive competitive environment can motivate learners and bring out their full potential. Therefore, when implemented strategically, competition in schools can be beneficial.\n

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

column4:
Refer to your essay plan which already outlines what 'you want to tell me' and write an introduction for your essay. 
[Recap] Your introduction should: 
  • have an opening that attracts the attention and interest of readers
  • address the keywords so that your reader knows how you are defining the terms [e.g., what does a competitive environment in school look like? What does something that is desirable (or not) look like? What makes it desirable (or not?)]
  • Outline the scope using your topic sentences 
  • State your thesis Statement which is your overall stand
You may refer to the attached essay plan with a sample introduction you can model after.
.
column5: \nIn our rapidly developing society, a child's future is often regarded as the top priority of parents. Many parents hope their children have bright and sustainable futures, and this is often only possible when students ace their examinations. As Singapore is a meritocratic society, only the top percentile can attain the best standard of education. As such, parents often push their children to strive for better grades. However, this pursuit would lead to a highly competitive learning environment where, on one hand, students would find themselves in such an overwhelming learning environment, leading to students having excessive stress and mental strain. Likewise, parents may disapprove of such an overly competitive learning environment, fearing that it might promote an unhealthy perception of education. Meanwhile, governments view competition in schools as a way to find and nurture national talent. Similarly, tuition companies may support a competitive education system, as it motivates worrisome parents to seek extra academic support, ultimately boosting their business. While it is clear that unhealthy competition can be harmful to students, a well-managed and positive competitive environment can motivate learners and bring out their full potential. Therefore, when implemented strategically, competition in schools can be beneficial.\n
column6: Get the student to reflect on whether they followed the required and correct processes to arrive at the answer, such as if they have read and understood the question, the process errors they made that caused them to write an inaccurate or incomplete description. If the student's response is lacking, provide a clear, actionable step for them to improve.

column4:
Refer to your essay plan which already outlines what 'you want to tell me' and write an introduction for your essay. 
[Recap] Your introduction should: 
  • have an opening that attracts the attention and interest of readers
  • address the keywords so that your reader knows how you are defining the terms [e.g., what does a competitive environment in school look like? What does something that is desirable (or not) look like? What makes it desirable (or not?)]
  • Outline the scope using your topic sentences 
  • State your thesis Statement which is your overall stand
You may refer to the attached essay plan with a sample introduction you can model after.
.
column5: \nIn our rapidly developing society, a child's future is often regarded as the top priority of parents. Many parents hope their children have bright and sustainable futures, and this is often only possible when students ace their examinations. As Singapore is a meritocratic society, only the top percentile can attain the best standard of education. As such, parents often push their children to strive for better grades. However, this pursuit would lead to a highly competitive learning environment where, on one hand, students would find themselves in such an overwhelming learning environment, leading to students having excessive stress and mental strain. Likewise, parents may disapprove of such an overly competitive learning environment, fearing that it might promote an unhealthy perception of education. Meanwhile, governments view competition in schools as a way to find and nurture national talent. Similarly, tuition companies may support a competitive education system, as it motivates worrisome parents to seek extra academic support, ultimately boosting their business. While it is clear that unhealthy competition can be harmful to students, a well-managed and positive competitive environment can motivate learners and bring out their full potential. Therefore, when implemented strategically, competition in schools can be beneficial.\n

column4:
Write a composition of at least 150 words about overcoming fear.

The pictures are provided to help you think about this topic. Your composition should be based on one or more of these pictures.
Consider the following points when you plan your composition:
What were you afraid of?
Why were you afraid of it?
How did you overcome your fear?

You may use the points in any order and include other relevant points as well.
column5:
I have always been afraid of Dobermanns. Their sharp teeth,strong bodies,and dark eyes made them look dangerous. Whenever I saw one, my stomach twisted, and I wanted to run in the other direction.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

I have always been afraid of Dobermanns. Their sharp teeth,strong bodies,and dark eyes made them look dangerous. Whenever I saw one, my stomach twisted, and I wanted to run in the other direction.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

What were you afraid of?

column5:
I have always been afraid of Dobermanns. Their sharp teeth,strong bodies,and dark eyes made them look dangerous. Whenever I saw one, my stomach twisted, and I wanted to run in the other direction.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

The pictures are provided to help you think about this topic. Your composition should be based on one or more of these pictures.

  • What were you afraid of?
  • Why were you afraid of it?
  • How did you overcome your fear?
 
You may use the points in any order and include other relevant points as well.
.
column5:
I have always been afraid of Dobermanns. Their sharp teeth,strong bodies,and dark eyes made them look dangerous. Whenever I saw one, my stomach twisted, and I wanted to run in the other direction.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

column5:
“Where has my parrot gone?” Amy, Dan’s older sister, exclaimed frantically. It was just after dinner and Amy had returned to her bedroom to feed her parrot only to find the cage open, empty and had a single red feather from her parrot inside it. “Oh no!” She thought, “My parents are not going to let me keep a pet ever again if I don’t find out who did it!” 
 Instantaneously, she sprung into action to try and find out who did it. First, she thought that she might not have locked the cage properly due to her carelessness but recalled clearly that she did lock the cage. Then, she started looking around the cage to see if there were any clues left behind by the culprit. Meanwhile, her younger brother had heard her shout. Waves of anxiety swept through him as he was the one who had set the bird free as he was watching and feeding it without his sister’s permission. At the birdcage, Amy found a piece of cloth with red and white stripes on it that looked like it had been torn off a shirt. She pondered whether the cloth could have been torn off the culprit’s shirt when they freed the bird.
 However, she could not rule anyone out yet as everyone in the family all had red and white striped shirts to wear on national day and they all had tears on them due to various accidents that happened. Below the cage, she found a packet of half-empty bird seeds as if someone was feeding the parrot before it escaped and also an overturned stool. She thought that it might have been her brother as he was the only one who needed a stool to unlock the cage but realised that it could not be him as he did not have the key to unlock the cage. 
 Amy then thought to check the security camera her parents had installed and noticed that there was a person standing near the cage at around 7 o'clock at night. She zoomed in on the figure and discovered that the person was short and standing near the cage. Although she could not see what he or she was doing, there was a loud squawk soon afterwards as the parrot escaped.
 Then, realisation dawned on Amy as she hurried to the place where she kept the keys and discovered the key was missing and there was only the spare key left. Realising her own brother had done it, she stormed up the stairs furiously and slammed open her brother’s bedroom door. When Amy opened the door, the waves of rage in her was palpable as she accused her brother indignantly, “I knew you let my parrot escape!” “I… I didn't do it!” Dan said shakily. “Yes you did! There was a piece of the cloth that you are wearing now and also a stool which you used to steal my keys!” Amy said angrily. “I am going to tell mom and dad!”
 The anxiety that coursed through Dan like a wave was palpable as he stuttered over his words. He did set the parrot free but only accidentally as he wanted to feed it at least once.
 In the end, Amy’s parents ordered Dan to pay back the money used to buy the parrot out of his own pocket money and apologize to Amy. She forgave him and decided to put this incident aside and let bygones be bygones.
column7:
Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."

It was just after dinner and Amy had returned to her bedroom to feed her parrot only to find the cage open, empty and had a single red feather from her parrot inside it. “Oh no!” She thought, “My parents are not going to let me keep a pet ever again if I don’t find out who did it!” 
 Instantaneously, she sprung into action to try and find out who did it. First, she thought that she might not have locked the cage properly due to her carelessness but recalled clearly that she did lock the cage. Then, she started looking around the cage to see if there were any clues left behind by the culprit. Meanwhile, her younger brother had heard her shout. Waves of anxiety swept through him as he was the one who had set the bird free as he was watching and feeding it without his sister’s permission. At the birdcage, Amy found a piece of cloth with red and white stripes on it that looked like it had been torn off a shirt. She pondered whether the cloth could have been torn off the culprit’s shirt when they freed the bird.
 However, she could not rule anyone out yet as everyone in the family all had red and white striped shirts to wear on national day and they all had tears on them due to various accidents that happened. Below the cage, she found a packet of half-empty bird seeds as if someone was feeding the parrot before it escaped and also an overturned stool. She thought that it might have been her brother as he was the only one who needed a stool to unlock the cage but realised that it could not be him as he did not have the key to unlock the cage. 
 Amy then thought to check the security camera her parents had installed and noticed that there was a person standing near the cage at around 7 o'clock at night. She zoomed in on the figure and discovered that the person was short and standing near the cage. Although she could not see what he or she was doing, there was a loud squawk soon afterwards as the parrot escaped.
 Then, realisation dawned on Amy as she hurried to the place where she kept the keys and discovered the key was missing and there was only the spare key left. Realising her own brother had done it, she stormed up the stairs furiously and slammed open her brother’s bedroom door. When Amy opened the door, the waves of rage in her was palpable as she accused her brother indignantly, “I knew you let my parrot escape!” “I… I didn't do it!” Dan said shakily. “Yes you did! There was a piece of the cloth that you are wearing now and also a stool which you used to steal my keys!” Amy said angrily. “I am going to tell mom and dad!”
 The anxiety that coursed through Dan like a wave was palpable as he stuttered over his words. He did set the parrot free but only accidentally as he wanted to feed it at least once.
 In the end, Amy’s parents ordered Dan to pay back the money used to buy the parrot out of his own pocket money and apologize to Amy. She forgave him and decided to put this incident aside and let bygones be bygones.
column7:
Adjective - Incorrect or inappropriate use of adjectives, such as using the wrong form (comparative, superlative): Incorrect: "She is more prettier than her sister." Correct: "She is prettier than her sister.",

Adverb - Incorrect use of adverbs, such as using an adjective instead of an adverb: Incorrect: "He runs quick." Correct: "He runs quickly.",

Capitalisation/ case - Incorrect use of uppercase and lowercase letters, especially for proper nouns and sentence beginnings: Incorrect: "i went to paris last summer." Correct: "I went to Paris last summer.",

Collocation - Incorrect pairing of words that do not naturally go together in English: Incorrect: "She made a big effort." Correct: "She made a great effort.",

Conjunction - Incorrect use or omission of conjunctions to link sentences or clauses. Incorrect: "Although it was cold outside, but I still went for a walk." Correct: "Although it was cold outside, I still went for a walk.",

Contraction - Incorrect use or omission of contractions, leading to confusion: Incorrect: "Its raining today." Correct: "It’s raining today.",

Determiner - Incorrect use or omission of determiners, such as articles, quantifiers and possessive determiners (e.g., a, an, the, much, many, my, your). Incorrect: "I love the nature." Correct: "I love nature.",

Noun - Incorrect noun forms, including pluralisation or uncountable nouns: Incorrect: "I have many homeworks." Correct: "I have a lot of homework.",

Other - Miscellaneous errors that don’t fit other categories: Incorrect: "I enjoy to the fullest life." Correct: "I enjoy life to the fullest.",

Particle - Incorrect use of particles, especially in phrasal verbs. Incorrect: "Please fill the form before leaving." Correct: "Please fill out the form before leaving.",

Possessive - Incorrect use of possessive forms (’s or s’). Incorrect: "The dog wagged it's tail." Correct: "The dog wagged its tail.",

Preposition - Incorrect or missing prepositions, leading to grammatical errors: Incorrect: "She is good in math." Correct: "She is good at math.",

Pronoun - Incorrect pronoun usage, including unclear references or agreement issues. Incorrect: "Each student must bring their book." Correct: "Each student must bring his or her book.",

Punctuation - Incorrect or missing punctuation marks that change the meaning. Incorrect: "Let’s eat Grandma." Correct: "Let’s eat, Grandma.",

Sentence - Errors related to sentence structure, such as fragments or run-ons: Incorrect: "When I arrived. I saw him." Correct: "When I arrived, I saw him.",

Space - Missing or extra spaces between words or punctuation: Incorrect: "I went tothe park." Correct: "I went to the park.",

Spelling - Incorrect spelling of words, affecting comprehension: Incorrect: "She recieved a letter." Correct: "She received a letter.",

Verb - Incorrect verb tense, agreement, or form (including gerunds/infinitives). Incorrect: "I look forward to meet you." Correct: "I look forward to meeting you.",

Word choice - Using an incorrect or suboptimal word that does not fit the context. Incorrect: "He is a criminal who has alluded capture." Correct: "He is a criminal who has eluded capture.",

Word order - Incorrect word order, making sentences sound unnatural or confusing: Incorrect: "She always is late." Correct: "She is always late."
